bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1949

div1.p: Truby congratulates Hench for his work in “that most terrible of all crippling diseases,” and asks him to help block the effort of Senator Lucas to have Gustaf E. Lambert admitted to the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor. He also states that Jernegan was the bravest volunteer.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1949
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18. CALIFORNIA
Feb. 17, '49
Dear Dr Hench-
div1.p:
I was delighted to get such
a nice long account of your European
trip and also the grand, overwhelming
news about your work in that most
terrible of all crippling diseases. I can
hardly wait for that preliminary report
and these which bid fair to follow
as in the case of Y.F. I would say [unclear]
that if you can arrest those cases and
prevent suffering & deformity, that the
Y.F. discovery in Cuba would prove to be
of less value to the great masses of people.
Anyway you could say with Reed “The prayer
that has been mine, for 20 years, that
I might be permitted to do something to
relieve human suffering has been granted.”

General Kean will be thrilled and
he will probably appraise your work
in more glowing terms than I can.
You may be sure no leak about your
work will come from here.

I am glad to know that Moran has finished
his manuscript and I will be pleased
to see it if he is willing. I hope he
is in better health than he was a year ago.

I am inclosing a clipping from the
A. & N. Journal of Feb 5. 49. showing that
Senator Lucas, Democrat from Ill., has
introduced a bill to place Gustaf E. Lambert
on the Roll of Honor with Walter Reed
and his guiney pigs. Please get busy with
the S.G., Kean, & Siler to see that the
usual steps are taken by the S.G. to block
that effort of Lambert's which takes place at each new session
of Congress. The files in the S.G.O. will show
everything that has been done before to
block passage of that bill.

I am glad that you told me about Mrs
Jernigan. I think she is most persistent
too, in her own way, about claiming all
sorts of help. In my book of letters recd, about
my Y.F. story there is a letter from Dr Hugh H.
Front of, Surgeon of the Jefferson Hospital,
Roanoke Vax after telling me how much
he enjoyed my book he had this to say:-
“We have had Mrs. Jernigan & her son in
the Hospital on numerous occasions as
patients. In fact young Jernigan left the
hospital recently. I am afraid this family
3
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18. CALIFORNIA
has an idea that the United States has to
support them” Dr. Trout is a Fellow
of the American College of Surgeons and a graduate
of the Univ of Va.

There is one thing Mrs. Jernigan might do
for you & me and that is identity her husband's picture in
that group with Reed by the Ambulance, under
the tree at Camp Lazear. You have in your
files my various comments on that very important
photo. I think that Jernegan is the man sitting
on the bench with his right shoulder against
the tree. He is between Dr. Cooke & Kissinger.

If you have occasion to write to Mrs. J. again
you might ask him if she has read what
I saywrote about Jernigan in my book on pp. 148,
150 & 173. No doubt she has seen it, but
she has never written to me. I thought J.
was the bravest of all the volunteers, for after the
infected bedding test he let mosquitoes have
a go at him and then late in the experiments, took
the blood test which gave him Y. F.

I expect Lambert told Mrs. J about you.
He is chronically active on the Y.F. subject
and when we were in Washington last year
Hanberry told me that Lambert complained to him
because he was not invited to the Walter Reed
celebration which we all attended in May. I have
AC
Tr
never been able to find any of Lambert's
letters which I had in my filing case. I
can't imagine where they are, but they may
turn up some day. However, I quoted all
of his statements that I believed, and the rest
were of no value, (in my opinion). I think
you must feel about Lambert very much as
Kean & I do. However, Ames trained Lambert
and was devoted to him and trusted him more
than he did Mrs. Lena Warner. I barely know
her.

In the October 1948 number of the Military
Surgeon, you will find an item & photo. of the Walter Reed exercises in Washington
last May. See pp 323 - 324. I think that Dr. Sawyer
should really have seen to it that proper
publicity in the papers & magazines was given
to that inmpressive program including your
splendid illustrated lecture. Perhaps I have
missed some reports of the event but I feel that
it was very poorly covered even in the Military Surgeon.

I shall keep on hoping that your activities
will soon bring you to S.F. again. All
of the Trubys want to see you & Mrs Hench and
hear all about Europe.

I will do as you say “Keep your fingers
crossed & say prayers for me” in your
promising work. I await that preliminary
report with great interest and hope it may
prove to be the second one of its kind given me by
my two good friends who really did big things for
humanity. I have been a great & enthuastic
onlooker only, but that is something too.
